column2: I have decided to embark on a pilgrimage to a significant site for the [Root.Religion.GetName] faith. It will doubtlessly be a long journey, but I think that it will be a worthwhile endeavor, and doubtlessly others belonging to the [Root.Religion.GetName] faith will look on me more favorably once I return home.
I will prove my devotion!

The kami are everywhere, and so are their servants and shrines. However, a pilgrimage needs to be to a significant location for anyone to take it seriously, and that gives me a smaller number of options.
I will visit the court of the [the_tenno.GetTitle]!
I will visit the grand shrine at Ise!
I will walk the Kumano route!
I will visit Mount Fuji!

There are certain sites in Japan to make a pilgrimage to, and those are generally where pilgrims like me would go, but as the Buddhist faith is rather widespread there are of course also other sites to be found elsewhere.
I will visit the many sites in Shikoku!
I will visit Mount Koya!
I will head outside Japan!

It is time to leave on my pilgrimage. Though it is possible that the journey will be both long and difficult I feel that I have made adequate preparations, and there is no reason to delay things any further.
I will prove my faith!

A pilgrim is generally expected to be an ascetic during their pilgrimage, and thus should avoid various immoral actions. I have of course been considering adhering to this during my pilgrimage, but perhaps it would be worse to try and fail than to not try at all.
Ascetism is commendable!
Ascetism isn't for me...

One day during my pilgrimage I encounter a wandering priest devoted to the [Root.Religion.GetName] faith. He inquires about my pilgrimage so far and is quite pleased when I tell him that I am making an effort to be ascetic, telling you that it is commendable and something that many struggle with..
I will be a better person!

After making the decision to try to be ascetic during my pilgrimage I have been considering how I am living my life in general, and I have concluded that one of my flaws is that I am rather proud. I have decided that this is something I should put behind me.
I will be a better person!

After making the decision to try to be ascetic during my pilgrimage I have been considering how I am living my life in general, and I have concluded that one of my flaws is that I am rather gluttonous. I have decided that this is something I should put behind me.
I will be a better person!

After making the decision to try to be ascetic during my pilgrimage I have been considering how I am living my life in general, and I have concluded that one of my flaws is that I am rather lustful. I have decided that this is something I should put behind me.
I will be a better person!

After making the decision to try to be ascetic during my pilgrimage I have been considering how I am living my life in general. Though I would not have said that I am overly proud, I have still concluded that I definitely could be a bit more humble, and I think I have taken a step in the right direction.
I made the right choice!

After making the decision to try to be ascetic during my pilgrimage I have been considering how I am living my life in general. Though I would not have said that I am overly gluttonous, I have still concluded that I definitely could be a bit more temperate, and I think I have taken a step in the right direction.
I made the right choice!

After making the decision to try to be ascetic during my pilgrimage I have been considering how I am living my life in general. Though I would not have said that I could be considered particularly lustful, I have still concluded that I definitely could be a bit more chaste, and I think I have taken a step in the right direction.
I made the right choice!

Though I decided that I wanted to be more ascetic during my pilgrimage I have not really been making much of an effort, and after a while on the road I conclude that I will not be able to really devote myself to this. It is bit shameful to know that I failed to do the right thing, even if only I know.
At least I tried...

One day during my pilgrimage I encounter a wandering priest devoted to the [Root.Religion.GetName] faith. He inquires about my pilgrimage so far, and when he learns just how little effort I have put into being ascetic he gets upset and calls me out on not being as devout as I should be.
At least I tried...

I decided that being ascetic during my pilgrimage would not be a good idea, and though a pilgrimage is a time to reflect on my faith and try to better myself I have instead been reconsidering how strictly I should follow its teachings, concluding that it would not necessarily be wrong for me to be a bit more proud.
I must be true to myself...

I decided that being ascetic during my pilgrimage would not be a good idea, and though a pilgrimage is a time to reflect on my faith and try to better myself I have instead been reconsidering how strictly I should follow its teachings, concluding that it would not necessarily be wrong for me to be a bit more gluttonous.
I must be true to myself...

I decided that being ascetic during my pilgrimage would not be a good idea, and though a pilgrimage is a time to reflect on my faith and try to better myself I have instead been reconsidering how strictly I should follow its teachings, concluding that it would not necessarily be wrong for me to be a bit more lustful.
I must be true to myself...

I decided that being ascetic during my pilgrimage would not be a good idea, and though a pilgrimage is a time to reflect on my faith and try to better myself I have instead been reconsidering how strictly I should follow its teachings, concluding that it would not necessarily be wrong for me to be a bit less humble.
I must be true to myself...

I decided that being ascetic during my pilgrimage would not be a good idea, and though a pilgrimage is a time to reflect on my faith and try to better myself I have instead been reconsidering how strictly I should follow its teachings, concluding that it would not necessarily be wrong for me to be a bit less temperate.
I must be true to myself...

I decided that being ascetic during my pilgrimage would not be a good idea, and though a pilgrimage is a time to reflect on my faith and try to better myself I have instead been reconsidering how strictly I should follow its teachings, concluding that it would not necessarily be wrong for me to be a bit less chaste.
I must be true to myself...

I knew that there possibly would be those that would be unhappy when I made the decision not to focus on ascetism during my pilgrimage, and I have been worrying a bit about someone lecturing me about it, but as far as I can tell nobody has seemed to care about me being less than ascetic during my pilgrimage.
It was the right decision!

One day on the road I come across a crippled dog with only three legs. It appears to have trouble walking, and whimpers from time to time. Though I know that I am supposed to refrain from killing during a pilgrimage, it is perhaps the lesser evil in a situation like this, since the dog clearly is suffering.
I won't take its life!
I can give it a quick death...
It doesn't know suffering... yet!

The dog follows me for a while despite having trouble walking, and it makes me feel rather sad that I cannot help it in any way. However, as I reach the next village one of the villagers takes pity on the dog and declares that he will adopt it and do what he can for it, which certainly is a welcome development.
It is good that someone cares!

Leaving the crippled dog behind I find myself reflecting on my normal approach to things, which often is violent, and perhaps a bit more cruel than it has to be. Though I would not go as far as to say that it is always wrong to use violence I should really try to be less cruel in the future.
I should be kinder!

I leave the crippled dog behind but find my thoughts returning to it several times during the following days. Though I could not have brought it with me I feel that there have been other situations in the past where I could have been a bit more helpful, and I decide that I should focus more on kindness in the future.
Kindness is the right path!

I leave the crippled dog behind but find my thoughts returning to it several times during the following days. It was unfortunate that I could not help it, but the only option I saw was to give it the mercy of a quick death, which would have been ever worse than leaving it since I should not kill during a pilgrimage.
Poor dog!

I draw my sword and approach the dog, striking swiftly and killing it before it can react. Unfortunately for me, another pilgrim is walking by as it happens, and he sees fit to berate me, claiming that it is more important for me to focus on my pilgrimage and what is proper during that than anything else.
Oh, shut up!

There was a time where I would not have seen fit to make the suffering of an animal shorter and perhaps even would have seen fit to draw it out, but I have decided that that is behind me and grant the dog a swift death. Though I would not go as far as to renounce violence I feel I could be less cruel in the future.
That was a kindness...

I draw my sword and approach the dog, striking swiftly and killing it before it can react. Though killing is not something I am supposed to do during a pilgrimage, letting an animal suffer needlessly seems worse to me. It is perhaps not a sentiment everyone would agree with, but in this particular instance I do not care.
That was a kindness...

I draw my sword and approach the dog, striking swiftly and killing it before it can react. With that done, I wipe my sword clean and sheathe it once more, then continue on my way. Mu pilgrimage is far from over, and I cannot afford to be distracted or delayed.
That was a kindness...

The crippled dog suspects nothing as I approach, and a precise cut with my sword severs one of the tendons in one of its remaining legs. It lets out a sound that is half a growl and half a whimper as it attempts to escape, but I ensure that that is not an option, and I spend the rest of the day inflicting further tortures on it
That was fun!

The crippled dog suspects nothing as I approach, and a precise cut with your sword severs one of the tendons in one of its remaining legs. It lets out a sound that is half a growl and half a whimper as it attempts to escape, but I ensure that that is not an option, and I spend the rest of the day inflicting further tortures on it.
That ended too soon!

I have been told that a pilgrim following the [Root.Religion.GetName] religion should avoid saying anything that could be considered immoral during the pilgrimage, and I have tried to behave acoordingly. However, in one village I come across an attractive villager, and I start questioning this prohibition.
I can say some immoral things...
It is wrong!

The attractive villager I made the comment do did appreciate what I say and tells me that I should know better than to engage in such behavior during a pilgrimage before leaving. Though word of what happened hopefully will not spread I still feel a bit humiliated by the experience, and I am convinced that I made a mistake.
It was just a joke!

The villager ignored my immoral words and leaves without comment. I am not certain what they thought of what I said, but it is quite clear that it was not as effective as I would have liked, and perhaps it was a mistake to not adhere to the supposed rules for a pilgrimage.
That could have gone worse...

The [pilgrims_lover.GetManWoman] is quite receptive to my words, and [pilgrims_lover.GetSheHe] gives me a smile and suggests that perhaps the two of us should head somewhere more private to perhaps to engage in certain other activities that might be of interest to me.
But of course!
I don't think so!

[pilgrims_lover.GetBestName] and I spend the night in each other's arms, and when the morning comes and I am about to leave [pilgrims_lover.GetSheHe] asks me whether the two of us will meet again. I cannot bring [pilgrims_lover.GetHerHim] with we on my journey, of course, but that does not necessarily mean we must be apart forever.
I have a place for you at home!
I don't want to see you again!

I resolve to say nothing immoral and continue on my way. A few villages later I overhear another pilgrim make immoral comments nearby, and the townspeople are quick to berate him. He is clearly humiliated by the experience, and it is likely that I made the right decision before.
Something to remember...

Though there was a time when I would have seen fit to make immoral comments to nearly every person I thought would be receptive I have started to feel that this is something that I should put behind me, not just for the duration of the pilgrimage but perhaps forever, as I want to try to be a better person.
Begone, lust!

I continue on my way and reflect on what I choose not to do a bit during the following days. Though I previously have not felt overly strongly on the subject of chastity I am starting to feel differently now, and I resolve to live my life in a chaste fashion from now on, as that feels quite appropriate.
Chastity is right!

I decide not to make an immoral comment and continue on my way, not feeling particularly strongly about the decision and not thinking too much about it over the course of the next few days. After all, I am on an important journey and have plenty of things to think about, and cannot afford to dwell on a small detail overly long.
Onwards!

I am aware that one of the rules pilgrims are supposed to adhere to during a pilgrimage is to abstain from alcohol, and I have been doing that so far even though I usually drink some on a somewhat frequent basis. However, one evening when I am having a meal at an inn one of the patrons there offers to buy me a drink.
Sorry, but I don't drink!
One drink won't hurt...

The patron that offered to buy me a drink seems a bit surprised by me turning down his offer, and he leaves the inn before long. After he has left some of the other patrons note that the man has made a habit of trying to trick pilgrims into drinking and that many pilgrims fail to refuse. They are evidently quite impressed by my resolve.
I made the right decision!

I refuse the offer of a drink, and the man who offered it to me merely shrugs and goes looking for another drinking partner. Noting that their behavior becomes worse and worse during the course of the evening as they drink more and more, I decide that I made the right decision, and also that I should try to be a bit more temperate in general.
Temperance is the right path!

I refuse the offer of a drink, and the man who offered it to me merely shrugs and goes looking for another drinking partner. The rest of the evening is uneventful, and I have a good night's sleep and a quick breakfast shortly after dawn before once more setting off on my journey, eager to reach my destination.
Onwards!

I accept the man's offer to buy me a drink, and once I start drinking I find that I have been missing it more than I thought I had. I order some more drinks after finishing the first, and decide that I really should not focus so much on temperance in the future as it simply is not worth the trouble.
I can indulge some more...

I accept the man's offer to buy me a drink, and drink it slowly once I receive it, intending for it to be the only drink I have. Before I have finished my drink another pilgrim enters the common room of the inn and notices that I am drinking, and he is quick to call me out for not avoiding alcohol during my pilgrimage.
Oh, shut up!

I accept the man's offer to buy me a drink, and drink it slowly once I receive it, intending for it to be the only drink I have. I have no trouble keeping that promise to myself, and the evening passes without anything notable happening. After a good night's sleep I have a quick breakfast before leaving the inn, eager to reach my destination.
Onwards!

I accept the man's offer to buy me a drink, and down in quickly after I receive it. Finding it to your taste, I order another, and then several more after that. The rest of the evening is a blur, and the next morning I wake up on the floor of the common room with a severe headache, which gets worse every time someone speaks louder than a whisper.
That... was a mistake...

One day on the road I come across a fellow pilgrim. The woman does not look pleased to see that she has company all of a sudden, and when it becomes clear that the two of us are heading in the same direction she starts complaining about how I have ruined the pilgrimage before launching into a series of insults.
I cannot let this slide...
I should try to de-escalate...

I inform the woman that she is being most unreasonable and should expect to share the road, and also tell her that she owes me an apology. She will have none of it, and an argument predictably breaks out. I am quite certain that she is the unreasonable party.
I am right, you are wrong!

I inform the woman that she is being most unreasonable and should expect to share the road, and also tell her that she owes me an apology. She will have none of it, and an argument predictably breaks out. A [Root.GetManWoman] of my rank should not have to endure such poor company!
I deserve better!

I inform the woman that she is being most unreasonable and should expect to share the road, and also tell her that she owes me an apology. She will have none of it, and an argument predictably breaks out. Though I would consider myself a humble person, I deserve better than this!
I am not at fault!

I inform the woman that she is being most unreasonable and should expect to share the road, and also tell her that she owes me an apology. She will have none of it, and an argument predictably breaks out as my patience has reached its limit.
I have no patience for fools!

I inform the woman that she is being most unreasonable and should expect to share the road, and also tell her that she owes me an apology. She will have none of it, and an argument predictably breaks out, and I feel more than justified in returning her insults.
The time for kindness is over!

I inform the woman that she is being most unreasonable and should expect to share the road, and also tell her that she owes me an apology. She will have none of it, and an argument predictably breaks out, and I inform the woman that she will pay dearly the next time she insults me.
Insult me and you'll regret it!

I inform the woman that she is being most unreasonable and should expect to share the road, and also tell her that she owes me an apology. She will have none of it, and an argument predictably breaks out, and I see no reason to hold back when it comes to returning the insults with interest.
Run away and cry!

I inform the woman that she is being most unreasonable and should expect to share the road, and also tell her that she owes me an apology. She will have none of it, and an argument predictably breaks out. Our quarrel attracts the attention of a priestess that is passing by, and she berates both of us.
I didn't start it!

I inform the woman that she is being most unreasonable and should expect to share the road, and also tell her that she owes me an apology. She declares that she is unwilling to share the road with me or give me an apology, and takes off in a different direction as soon as she can.
Good riddance!

I calmly explain to the woman that I am just another pilgrim and that this is the best route for me, and she listens to my words before offering me what appears to be a sincere apology. Though I felt tempted to return her insults with interest I conclude that it was the right decision to go for something more diplomatic.
Cruelty is uncalled for!

I calmly explain to the woman that I am just another pilgrim and that this is the best route for me, and she listens to my words before offering me what appears to be a sincere apology. Though I felt tempted to threaten her with violence when she insulted me I conclude that it was the right decision to go for something more diplomatic.
I know how to keep my temper!

I calmly explain to the woman that I am just another pilgrim and that this is the best route for me, and she listens to my words before offering me what appears to be a sincere apology. Though there are many that would have resorted to violence or that would have returned the insults I feel that approaching the matter with kindness was correct.
Kindness is the right path!

I calmly explain to the woman that I am just another pilgrim and that this is the best route for me, and she listens to my words before offering me what appears to be a sincere apology. Though there are many that would have resorted to violence or that would have returned the insults I feel that approaching the matter with patience was correct.
Patience is the right path!

I calmly explain to the woman that I am just another pilgrim and that this is the best route for me, and she listens to my words before offering me what appears to be a sincere apology. Though I usually would have expected a better apology, I am on a pilgrimage to better myself, and I decide to put my pride aside.
I should be humber!

I calmly explain to the woman that I am just another pilgrim and that this is the best route for me, and she listens to my words before offering me what appears to be a sincere apology. There are those that would not have considered a mere apology acceptable after their pride was injured, but I can see how being humble is the right decision.
Humility is the right path!

I calmly explain to the woman that I am just another pilgrim and that this is the best route for me, and she listens to my words before offering me what appears to be a sincere apology. Though I was rather less insistent than I usually would have been, it clearly worked out in mu favor, and I conclude that I should be less stubborn in general.
Stubborness is overrated!

I calmly explain to the woman that I am just another pilgrim and that this is the best route for me, and she listens to my words before offering me what appears to be a sincere apology. Over the next few days I look back at some other incidents in the past and start seeing how I could have handled them more diplomatically.
I know what to say now!

I calmly explain to the woman that I am just another pilgrim and that this is the best route for me, and though she calms down a bit she tells me that she prefers solitude even so, conceding that she could be the one to take a different route. True to her words, she elects to head off in a different direction almost immediately.
Perhaps it is for the best...

Before setting off on my pilgrimage you made the customary donations to nearby temples to prove my devotion, but even so I brought quite a bit of money on my journey. Recently, I have been considering the fact that this is not quite in line with what is expected of me during a pilgrimage, and perhaps I should make another donation.
I can give a bit more to charity...
I have given more than enough!

I make sure to stop by the next temple I come across to hand over a substantial amount of money to the [Root.Religion.GetName] priests found there. They are quite grateful to receive such a donation, and tell me that it is good that I saw fit to donate to charity.
I only did what was right!

I make sure to stop by the next temple I come across to hand over a substantial amount of money to the [Root.Religion.GetName] priests found there. After leaving I start considering just how much money I normally have been earning compared to how much I have been able to spend, and I conclude that I really do not need that much money.
Greed is overrated!

I make sure to stop by the next temple I come across to hand over a substantial amount of money to the [Root.Religion.GetName] priests found there. Later on I start considering whether I could donate to temples more often, and conclude that it should be rather easy to arrange that as I have more than enough money.
Charity is the right path!

I make sure to stop by the next temple I come across to hand over a substantial amount of money to the [Root.Religion.GetName] priests found there. Normally, I would consider doing so a bit beneath me, but I have decided that I should better myself during my pilgrimage and that becoming more humble is the right move.
Pride is a problem!

I make sure to stop by the next temple I come across to hand over a substantial amount of money to the [Root.Religion.GetName] priests found there. They are a bit surprised to learn that I was willing to set my own good aside, but they praise me for being humble enough to admit that I had made a mistake.
I don't mind being humble!

I make sure to stop by the next temple I come across to hand over a substantial amount of money to the [Root.Religion.GetName] priests found there. They praise ,e for my kindness, and I take their words to heart and decide that from now on I should endeavor to be kind more often than I have been in the past.
I should be kind more often!

I make sure to stop by the next temple I come across to hand over a substantial amount of money to the [Root.Religion.GetName] priests found there, and then leave the temple right away. I have yet to reach my destination, after all, and cannot afford to be distracted by minor things along the road.
Onwards!

I am in the middle of a discussion with a [Root.Religion.GetName] priest at a small shrine when I suddenly notice that the sun is lower on the horizon than I had thought it was. Since I am supposed to make sure that I get to my inn before dark during a pilgrimage, I might need to leave sooner rather than later, even though the priest might be upset.
I must depart at once!
I can stay a while and listen...

The priest is surprised at first when I interrupt him to tell him that I need to leave at once, but then he notices just how low the sun is on the horizon and tells me that he is sorry to have taken up so much of my time. Furthermore, he says that it is rather refreshing to meet a pilgrim that actually cares about adhering to the rules for a pilgrimage.
I knew he'd understand!

I take my leave and hurry away from the temple, doing my best to make up for lost time. Though I normally would have taken it easy I have come to the conclusion that that is not what I really want to do, and I resolve to become less slothful in order to better myself during my pilgrimage.
I cannot afford to rest!

I take my leave and hurry away from the temple, doing my best to make up for lost time. I am no stranger to working hard at times when something unexpected happens, and as I hurry towards the next village I decide that I should make an effort to always work hard from now on to try to have more time available for unforeseen issues that might arise.
I must work hard to succeed!

The priest is surprised when I interrupt him and to tell him that I need to leave at once. When I tell him that it is getting late and that I need to hurry if I am to reach the next village with an inn before dark he gets annoyed and tells me that I should not have stopped in the first place if I did not think to plan ahead.
I would have thought he'd be pleased...

I stay at the temple until the priest finally is done talking, at which point the sun barely is above the horizon. I am unsure whether I could reach the nearest village with an inn before dark even if I really make an effort, and I decide that it is not really worth trying and that there is nothing wrong with taking it easy.
I can afford to relax...

I stay at the temple until the priest finally is done talking, at which point the sun barely is above the horizon. Though I perhaps could have made it to the nearest village with an inn before dark if I had made an effort Iu decide that it really is not worth trying, and as I head off at a rather slow pace I decide that I need to learn to relax.
I can't work all the time...

The priest keeps talking for a good while and it is almost dark before he finally stops. As I prepare to leave he takes the time to tell me that I really should have been more mindful of the fact that I needed to depart sooner. It is rather clear that he does not seem to think that the fact that he kept talking was why I remained at the temple.
But I didn't want to upset you!

The priest keeps talking for a good while and it is almost dark before he finally stops. He is evidently aware of the fact that this makes it unlikely that I will reach an inn before dark as he makes sure to tell me that I need not worry about that as keeping him company and listening to him without interruption certainly justifies being out after dark.
Good to hear!

It is almost dark before the priest stops talking long enough for me to leave, and I find myself racing the sunset as I hurry towards where I think that the nearest inn is located. Twilight has arrived by the time that I enter the inn, but twilight is not the same as darkness, so I managed to get there in time.
I barely made it...

I wake up well before dawn one morning and cannot fall asleep again, and I start to wonder whether it would be a good idea to set off early so that I perhaps might reach my destination sooner. I know that I technically am not supposed to leave my inn during the night during a pilgrimage unless it is unavoidable, but perhaps there are expections?
An early start is right!
There are rules to follow...

I head down to the common room and eat a quick breakfast before gathering my belongings and setting off from the inn. As I depart I consider the fact that I normally would have been willing to wait patiently for things to happen, but it has at times been rather difficult, and I do not really feel that it is something I want keep doing.
Maybe I'm a bit impatient...

I head down to the common room and eat a quick breakfast before gathering my belongings and setting off from the inn. I am no stranger to not resting when there is something to do, and looking back I can see how being a bit more diligent would have been beneficial. Since I am on a pilgrimage partially to better myself, I resolve to become more diligent from now on.
I must not waste time!

I head down to the common room and eat a quick breakfast before gathering my belongings and setting off from the inn. Normally, I would have welcomed any excuse to take it easy, but I have started to come to the conclusion that that is often detrimental, and I resolve to be less slothful in the future.
I must work harder!

I head down to the common room and eat a quick breakfast before gathering my belongings and heading for the door. As I am about to step outside another pilgrim that has been staying at the same inn comes down the stairs and spots me, and she quickly calls me out on leaving an inn during the night.
I can't please everyone...

I head down to the common room and eat a quick breakfast before gathering my belongings and setting off from the inn. I have quite far to travel before I reach my destination, and I cannot affort to waste time, and since nobody seems to have noticed that I am breaking the rules it probably will not be anything I come to regret.
Onwards!

I decide that I should remain at the inn until dawn, as is expected of me. I spend the time reflecting on the fact that there are many things in life that I cannot control, and that that sometimes mean I have to wait on things, and I resolve to be a bit more patient moving forward.
Good things come to those that wait!

I decide that I should remain at the inn until dawn, as is expected of me. As I do not really have anything to do the time is not spent in a productive manner, but I find that I do not mind this as much as I had expected, and I decide that perhaps it would not be a bad idea to take it easy more often.
I should not work so hard...

I decide that I should remain at the inn until dawn, as is expected of me. I do not bother trying to be productive, and even though I initially planned to leave at dawn I find myself lingering at the inn for a while longer after that since I have come to feel that there really is no need to rush.
I can relax more often...

I decide that I should remain at the inn until dawn, as is expected of me. As I hear the other people that have stayed overnight start moving about I head down to eat a quick breakfast, and as the sun is above the horizon after I am done I gather my belongings and set off, seeing as I no longer risk breaking the rules.
Onwards!
The Chrysanthemum Throne

After a long journey I have finally arrived at my destination: The court of the [the_tenno.GetTitle].\nThough I have not yet entered the august presence of [the_tenno.GetBestName] [the_tenno.GetHerselfHimself] and thus have not beheld the actual Chrysanthemum Throne I still feel a sense of awe, and judging by the looks on the faces of the other pilgrims I have seen I am not the only one that is impressed.\nAside from briefly being stopped by the guards so that they could confirm my identity and my purpose, none of the locals have really paid attention to me yet.
I need to be on my best behavior!

I could spend weeks or even months wandering the court of the [the_tenno.GetTitle] without getting to see [the_tenno.GetHerHim] or the Chrysanthemum Throne itself, and none would fault me for not bothering [the_tenno.GetHerHim], but I have travelled far and am not just any common pilgrim, so perhaps it would be possible to get an audience.
I will try to get an audience!
I'd rather not bother [the_tenno.GetHerHim]...

One of the lesser court officials informs me that [From.GetBestName] has arrived at my court on a pilgrimage and that [From.GetSheHe] is requesting an audience with me. It is unclear if there is a particular reason for this audience or not, and it is not out of line to ask for an audience, but it is up to me wether I want to accept the request or not.
I don't have time for this...
I can spare the time!
We can meet... in the dungeon!

A messenger arrives to inform me that the [the_tenno.GetTitle] is busy with affairs of state for the time being and cannot spare the time to grant me the audience I seek.
